page.title: 02The Canal at Deepcut
page.content: The{Basingstoke Canal}was one of the first opened in Southern England to be part of a national waterway between the River Thames and the English and British Channels. The canal which was used for trade purposes, never went beyond Basingstoke and was 59km long. The cutting of the part of the canal which passes through Ash, Frimley, Pirbright & Woking was begun in 1788. In a distance of 25km there is a rise of 60m therefore 29 locks were built which had to be big enough to allow boats 22m long and 4m wide to pass. The canal rose 30m by means of 14 locks within a 3km stretch to reach the entrance of the great thousand yard cutting 22m deep in places. This area became known as{Deepcut. In 1839 the London and South Western Railway was completed from London to Basingstoke.
